{{other persons|Johnny Moore}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Johnny B. Moore | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Johnny Belle Moore | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1950|1|24|mf=y}}
[[Clarksdale, Mississippi|Clarksdale]], [[Mississippi]], [[United States]] | death_date = | origin = | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Chicago blues]], [[electric blues]] | occupation = [[Guitarist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1970s–present | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Johnny B. Moore''' (born '''Johnny Belle Moore''', January 24, 1950, [[Clarksdale, Mississippi|Clarksdale]], [[Mississippi]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[electric blues]] [[guitarist]], [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]].{{cite web|author=Bill Dahl |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/johnny-b-moore-mn0000241618/biography |title=Johnny B. Moore | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1950-01-24 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} He was a member of [[Koko Taylor]]'s backing band in the mid-1970s, but has recorded nine solo albums since 1987. Moore's music retains a link to the earlier Chicago blues of [[Jimmy Reed]] and [[Muddy Waters]], who also travelled to the Windy City from the [[Mississippi delta]]. "If Johnny B. Moore isn't a star in the making," stated [[Allmusic]]'s Bill Dahl, "there's no justice in the world." The European blues historian Gérard Herzhaft commented that "[Moore's] albums reflect a strong Delta flavor that is refreshing in the present blues scene, dominated by rock or funk overtones."{{cite book | first= Gérard | last= Herzhaft | year= 1997 | title= Encyclopedia of the blues | edition= 2nd | publisher= The University of Arkansas Press | location= Fayetteville | isbn= 1-55728-452-0 | page= 56}} However, the blues historian, Tony Russell, noted in 1997 that Moore "was still one of Chicago's interesting secrets".{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues - From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher=Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 148 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} ==Biography== Moore's [[Baptists|Baptist]] [[Minister (Christianity)|minister]] father, Floyd Moore, taught his son to play the guitar from the age of seven. [[John Lee Hooker]]'s "[[Boogie Chillen']]," was the first piece Moore mastered, but he was influenced by the style of [[Magic Sam]]. In his early days Moore performed [[gospel music]] in his hometown of Clarksdale, and later in Chicago with the Gospel Keys group. In 1964, the teenage Moore relocated to Chicago with his father. In high school Moore learned to read music, and his education was enhanced listening to blues records with Letha Jones, [[Little Johnny Jones (pianist)|Little Johnny Jones]]' widow. By the late 1960s Moore was working in a lamp factory, but after work continued to play. He was further tutored by Jimmy Reed, whom he first met in his childhood, and then with the Charles Spiers band. By 1975, Moore found a further musical outlet by joining Koko Taylor's backing band, the Blues Machine, as [[lead guitarist]]. His lead guitar work appeared on Taylor's album ''[[The Earthshaker]]'' (1978). He toured separately with Taylor and [[Willie Dixon]], undertaking European jaunts with both, and worked in Dixon's band until the latter's death in 1992. He also augmented his income by appearing more often under his own name. Moore appeared on the bill on June 10, 1984, at the inaugural [[Chicago Blues Festival]].{{cite book | first= Karen | last= Hanson | year= 2007 | title= Today's Chicago Blues | edition= 1st | publisher= Lake Claremont Press | location= Chicago, Illinois | isbn= 978-1-893121-19-5 | page= 56}} His debut album, ''Hard Times'', was released in 1987 on the B.L.U.E.S. label. In the 1990s Moore recorded six more efforts of his own, and started the new millennium with ''Born in Clarksdale, Mississippi'' (2001) for the [[Austria]]n based Wolf [[record label]].{{cite web |url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G2-2874000045.html |title=Johnny B. Moore 1950- |author=Manheim, James M. |publisher=Encyclopedia.com |accessdate=August 13, 2010}} His ''Live at Blue Chicago'' (1996), was recorded in that club's basement, and featured [[Ken Saydak]] on keyboards. The 1999 [[live album]], ''Acoustic Blue Chicago'' featured [[Willie Kent]], [[Lester Davenport]] and [[Bonnie Lee]].{{cite web|author=Earl Simmons |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/acoustic-blue-chicago-mw0000237740 |title=Acoustic Blue Chicago - Johnny B. Moore | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} Moore more often used a [[Slide guitar|bottleneck]] on his guitar solos. Moore appeared again at the Chicago Blues Festival in 2002. In addition, he has made several guest appearances on other blues musicians albums. These included Willie Kent's ''Too Hurt to Cry'' (1994).{{cite web|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=sScEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA133&dq=%22JOHNNY+B.+MOORE%22&hl=en&ei=U1RlTJPeDN6VOJLf6dUN&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCwQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=%22JOHNNY%20B.%20MOORE%22&f=false |title=JazzTimes - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} His most recent album, ''Rockin' in the Same Old Boat'' (2003), was described by Allmusic's [[music journalism|journalist]], Matt Collar, as "Moore's hard-driving lead guitar lines are well intact as is his off-hand, sometimes slurred vocal delivery".{{cite web|author=Matt Collar |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/rockin-in-the-same-old-boat-mw0000317063 |title=Rockin' in the Same Old Boat - Johnny B. Moore | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Year of release !Album title !Record label |- |1987 |''Hard Times'' |B.L.U.E.S. |- |1993 |''Lonesome Blues Chicago Blues Session, Vol. 5'' |Wolf Records |- |1996 |''Johnny B. Moore'' |[[Delmark Records|Delmark]] |- |1996 |''Live at Blue Chicago'' (live album) |Delmark |- |1997 |''Trouble World'' |Delmark |- |1997 |''911 Blues'' |Wolf |- |1999 |''Acoustic Blue Chicago'' (live album) |Blue Chicago |- |2001 |''Born in Clarksdale, Mississippi'' |Wolf |- |2003 |''Rockin' in the Same Old Boat'' |Delmark |}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/johnny-b-moore-mn0000241618/discography |title=Johnny B. Moore | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1950-01-24 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} ==See also== *[[List of Chicago blues musicians]] *[[List of electric blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.delmark.com/delmark.688.htm Delmark.com review of ''Live At Blue Chicago''] *[http://www.google.co.uk/images?hl=en&rlz=1W1RNTN_en&q=%22JOHNNY+B.+Moore%22&um=1&ie=UTF-8&source=univ&ei=T2xlTJvKMMfKjAe7vYDsCw&sa=X&oi=image_result_group&ct=title&resnum=4&ved=0CDgQsAQwAw&biw=1419&bih=699 Images of Moore] {{Authority control|VIAF=63620315}} {{Persondata | NAME = Moore, Johnny B. | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[electric blues]] guitarist, singer and songwriter | DATE OF BIRTH = January 24, 1950 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Clarksdale, Mississippi]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Moore, Johnny B.}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Mississippi]] [[Category:Chicago blues musicians]] [[Category:Electric blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Mississippi]] [[Category:People from Clarksdale, Mississippi]]
